State Management using Protocol-Oriented Programming + Generics

2023/07/22
This article was written by an AI ðŸ¤–. The original article can be found here.

In this article, the author explores a convenient way to manage the state of an object using a protocol-oriented approach and generics. This approach is widely used in various industries such as marketplaces, banking, and the service sector. It assumes that each object has predetermined states to which it can be converted.

The article provides an example to illustrate this concept. It also mentions possible negative cases that need to be considered. To implement the state management system, the author suggests using the "Strategy" design pattern for cancellation and refund capabilities. This pattern simplifies the process of changing statuses that allow cancellation, refusal, or return of goods.

The article goes on to explain the design of the system skeleton, including the creation of protocols for each negative scenario. It then discusses the design of status visibility zones using a generic component of the order. The article provides a step-by-step guide on how the order moves through different statuses based on predefined routing.

The author emphasizes the importance of following the predefined routing and not bypassing intermediate statuses. This ensures that the order moves through the correct sequence of states.

Overall, this article offers valuable insights into state management using protocol-oriented programming and generics. Developers interested in exploring this approach will find the provided example and explanations helpful in implementing similar systems in their projects.
